message_1: Find the smallest integer "n" such that the temporal logic formula: $\square(p\rightarrow\F q)$ is true, where "p" and "q" are boolean variables and $\square$ and $\F$ represent the "always" and "eventually" temporal operators, respectively.
message_2:
The temporal logic formula $\square(p\rightarrow\F q)$ can be interpreted as follows: "For all time points, if p is true, then q will eventually be true." To find the smallest integer "n" that makes this formula true, we need to consider the possible values of p and q and the behavior of the temporal operators.

There are two cases to consider:

1. If p is false at any time point, then the implication $p\rightarrow\F q$ is vacuously true, as an implication with a false antecedent is always true. In this case, the formula $\square(p\rightarrow\F q)$ is true, and n can be any non-negative integer.

2. If p is true at any time point, then we need q to be true at some future time point to satisfy the implication $p\rightarrow\F q$. In this case, the smallest integer n would be the smallest number of time points it takes for q to become true after p is true.

Since the first case allows for the formula to be true with any non-negative integer, the smallest integer "n" that makes the temporal logic formula $\square(p\rightarrow\F q)$ true is 0.
